Asher Yoel Rosinger, MPH

Digital Curriculum Vitae

ABOUT

I am a human biologist in the Anthropology Department at the University of Georgia with a Master's in Public Health in Epidemiology. My work addresses how humans respond to changing nutritional and economic environments through water and diet intake and the significance of these relationships for short- and long-term health and nutrition. My research among Tsimane’ forager-horticulturalists in the Bolivian Amazon addresses an exciting new avenue in biological anthropology evaluating how hydration strategies relate to variation in hydration, water-related diseases, and immune activation during lifestyle transitions.

Media Coverage

2014 National Geographic feature story “The Evolution of Diet” in September 2014 edition:
www.nationalgeographic.com/foodfeatures/evolution-of-diet

Skills & Languages

Programming and Data Analysis: Stata (proficient), SPSS (competent), and Mplus (beginner) to perform statistical analysis using linear and logistic regression, categorical data analysis, multi-level modeling, latent class analysis, and longitudinal analysis. Qualitative analysis using MaxQDA (beginner).
Languages: English (native); Spanish (proficient); Tsimane’ (partially conversational); Hebrew (basic)

Areas of Specialization

Biological, nutritional, and economic anthropology; anthropology of water; energetics; epidemiology; hydration; obesity; infectious disease; quantitative methods; Bolivia; Amazonia.

Research

7/12 - 6/14 Study Principal. Investigator. Hydration Strategies, Nutrition, and Health During a Lifestyle Transition in the Bolivian Amazon. Beni, Bolivia.
  • Conducted semi-structured interviews regarding water and hydration and focal follows with 38 adults in 2 communities & urine analysis.
  • Administered 2 rounds of interviews with 63 households (n=250) regarding diet,economics, and health; conducted anthropometrics & urine analysis.
  • Collected dried blood spots, fecal, and hair samples from a subsample of 110 participants; conducted 3 rounds of water quality analysis in both communities.
  • Led, trained, and arranged logistics for field team of four.
01/12 - 05/12 Student Intern, National Exposure Research Laboratory, Environmental Protection Agency, Athens, GA.
“Water quality analysis, agricultural runoff in watersheds, salmonella and E. coli.”
  • Collected and analyzed water samples for salmonella, E. coli, enterococci, totalcoliforms, and turbidity; DNA extraction methods, and data analysis.
08/11 - 12/11 Investigator. Sleep, stress, and cold/flu infections among college undergraduates. Field Epidemiology, College of Public Health, UGA.
  • Designed, administered, and analyzed survey data from 104 undergraduatestudents at UGA.
06/10 - 08/10 Field Assistant and Preliminary Research; NSF Field School; Beni, Bolivia
  • Led sessions on data collection and data analysis methods for PhD anthropology students; conducted 30 qualitative interviews.
08/08 - 05/10 Graduate Research Assistant, Anthropology Department, UGA, Athens, GA
  • Health and Human Biology Laboratory manager, data analysis in Stata, systematic review of soil transmitted helminthes treatments, and grant writing.
06/09 - 07/09 Preliminary Dissertation Research;NSF Field School; Beni, Bolivia
  • Conducted survey, time allocation, participant observation and qualitative interviews.
08/05 - 05/07 Research Assistant, Psychology Department, UNC Chapel Hill, NC
  • Administered and analyzed eye tracking and language experiments exploring relationship between reading comprehension and memory retention.
